thread.title_full: 49ers’ Colin Kaepernick plan finally looks like right move | New York Post

author: Bart Hubbuch
title: 49ers’ Colin Kaepernick plan finally looks like right move
text:
The 49ers couldn’t blame Colin Kaepernick for this loss.
Off to a four-game start so bad some were even calling for him to be benched in favor of Blaine Gabbert, the beleaguered quarterback finally looked comfortable in the pocket and nearly carried San Francisco back into the win column before Big Blue pulled out a 30-27 victory at MetLife Stadium.
Having thrown five interceptions and no touchdowns in San Francisco’s previous two games, Kaepernick turned back the clock — at least with his arm — to his Super Bowl run of 2012 to help the struggling Niners give the Giants a surprising dogfight.
Not that Kaepernick was satisfied after San Francisco fell to 1-4 — its worst record since then-head coach Mike Singletary opened 0-5 in 2010, his final season as coach.
“It was good offensively to get in a rhythm like that,” Kaepernick said. “It’s something we can build on moving forward. But we have to win games.”
New 49ers coach Jim Tomsula and his staff have been trying to make Kaepernick a pocket passer, a plan that before Sunday night had drawn criticism for taking away one of Kaepernick’s best assets — his legs.
But with the Giants missing six key defensive players due to injury (middle linebacker Jon Beason was the latest victim, exiting early in the first quarter due to a concussion), Kaepernick had more than enough time to get comfortable with his dropbacks.
The result had to be encouraging: Kaepernick completed 23-of-35 passes for 262 yards and two touchdowns. Best of all, the Niners’ Turnover Machine played mistake-free football for four entire quarters.
That was in sharp contrast to San Francisco’s previous two games, which featured five Kaepernick interceptions and no TDs. Included in that wreckage was a pair of pick-six interceptions by Kaepernick thrown at the start of a 47-7 loss to the Cardinals in Week 3.
And to think: The Giants came in hoping Kaepernick would stay in the pocket because they thought it would make him less of a threat.
Even as a single threat, though, the Giants had trouble all night containing Kaepernick. He carried just three times for 23 yards but still gave the Big Blue defense fits.
Beckham saved his best for last, too, directing the Niners on a pair of touchdown marches in the fourth quarter that tied the game and then gave San Francisco the lead.
Kaepernick’s first clutch play in the fourth came with 11:53 left, when he hit tight end Brent Celek with a 5-yard TD pass to tie the game 20-20.
After the Giants took a 23-20 lead with a 24-yard Josh Brown field goal, Kaepernick promptly marched San Francisco downfield again to set up a two-yard scoring dive from Hyde to give the Niners a lead they thought would hold up.
It didn’t — Larry Donnell’s circus catch with 21 seconds left capped the Giants’ comeback — but at least for one week, Kaepernick’s legion of critics couldn’t pin this one on him.
“I’m never going to accept losing,” Kaepernick said, “and never going to be happy with a loss.”
